conclusion: Sphere A is stationary on the inclined plane with zero tension in the wire, meaning all forces acting on it must balance.
Sphere A is on an inclined plane, connected to a wire parallel to the plane, and sphere B is to the right of sphere A at the same height, separated by distance d.
The forces acting on sphere A are weight (mg) acting downward, normal force (N_A) from the inclined plane perpendicular to the plane, and electrostatic force (F_e) from sphere B.
The weight mg can be decomposed into components: parallel to the inclined plane (mg·sin(θ)) and perpendicular to the inclined plane (mg·cos(θ)).
For equilibrium perpendicular to the inclined plane, N_A - mg·cos(θ) = 0, so N_A = mg·cos(θ).
The electrostatic force between two charges is given by Coulomb's law: F_e = k·q₁·q₂/r². Here, F_e = k·q²/d² since both spheres have charge +q and are separated by distance d.
The electrostatic force F_e acts horizontally, and its components are: parallel to the inclined plane (F_e·cos(θ)) and perpendicular to the inclined plane (F_e·sin(θ)).
For equilibrium parallel to the inclined plane, F_e·cos(θ) - mg·sin(θ) = 0.
Substituting F_e = k·q²/d² into the parallel force balance equation gives: k·q²/d² · cos(θ) = mg·sin(θ).
Rearranging the equation gives q²/d² = (mg·sin(θ))/(k·cos(θ)), which simplifies to q²/d² = (mg·tan(θ))/k.
Taking the square root of both sides gives q/d = √(mg·tan(θ)/k).
